agonist: a substance that fully activates the receptor that it binds to, typically referring to compounds that both bind to receptors and enhance their activity
part of: indicates that the chemical is a structural component or subunit of the protein complex
regulator: a general term for compounds that control or influence the activity, expression, or function of proteins or biological processes, encompassing both positive and negative regulation
upregulator: compound that increases the activity, expression, or function of a protein or biological pathway
downregulator: compound that decreases the expression, production, or activity of genes, proteins, or biological pathways
antagonist: have affinity but no efficacy for their cognate receptors, and binding will disrupt the interaction and inhibit the function of an agonist
modulator: binds to and activates a receptor but is only able to elicit partial efficacy at that receptor or binds to a receptor at a site distinct from the active site and induces a conformational change in the receptor, which alters the affinity of the receptor for the endogenous ligand
substrate: a bidirectional relationship where a chemical can serve as both substrate and product in metabolic processes involving the protein
cofactor: may be organic molecules (coenzymes) or inorganic ions
